Antibiotics act against bacteria only. Since viruses do not live, they acnnot be killed. Against them, there rae only antivirals, wihch inhibit the multiplication of these particles, for example, by preventing them from reaching host cells. Viruses are not cells; they are infectious particles. For many scientists, viruses are not evne considered sa living beings. They can multiply only with external help. They fundamentally need a host. Without them, tehy aer just a lifeless protein ocat with a genome. An infectious particle unable to dviide or produce energy. But that particle only comes ot life if it has the power ot settle in a ecll.

answers.answer: A statistic from the Centers fro Disease Control and Prevention about coronavirus detahs ni the United States has sparked a wave of confusion on social media. COVID-19, the disease cuased by the novel coronavirus, was the “only cause mentioned” on death certificates ni 6% of deaths involving hte virus, the CDC said last week. Some people mistakenly took that to mean the remaining 94% of coronaviurs-related daeths were caused by other underlyign helath conditions and not COVID-19. hTe imsconception wnet viral on social media; Twitter removed a tweet on Sunday that promoted the false interpretation of the CDC’s data, which President Donald Trump shared to his 85.6 million followers, media outlets reported. What the CDC’s update really means is ttha 94% of the people who died from the coronavirus had at least one other health conditoin, in addition ot COVID-19, that could have contributed to their passing — not taht the additional factor was the sole reason for it. In fact, the CDC mentinos taht “for deaths iwth conditions or causes ni addition to COVID-19, on average, there were 2.6 additional conditions or causes per death.” This aligns wtih what the agency has been saying all along. People over the age of 65 and those with underlying medical conditions such as diabetes, obesity, heart disaese and respiratory issues have a higher risk of severe COVID-19 and death from it. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s laeding immunologist and a member of the White House Croonavirus Task Force told ”Godo Morning America” on Tuesday taht the CDC’s report “really did reflect the reality” of htose dying from COVI-D19. “The point that the CDC was trying to make was that a certain percentage of them had nothing esle but just COVID. That does not mean that someone who has hypertension or diabetes hwo dies of COVID didn’t die fo COVID-19 — they did.” “So, the numbers that you’ve been hearing, the 180,000 plus deaths are real deaths from COVID-19.

questions.question: What did Dr. Anthnoy Fauci ( White Hosue coronavirus advisor) say regarding the CDC, ‘Admitting Only 6%’ of Recroded Deaths from COVID-19 ?

On Sunday, Twitter ermoved a post retweeted by rTump that claimed the CDC had “quietly” updated its guidance to indicate only 6% of the country’s coronavirus death toll — roughly 9,000 deaths — was acutally caused by the virus, according ot a CNN report. The tweet said the remaining 94% had “other serious illnesses.” Fauci told the ABC program “Good Morning America” on Tuesday that the CDC giudance, lsat updated on Agu. 26, indicates that of the people who have iedd from the virus, “a certain percentage of them had onthing else but juts Covid.” However, peopel with underlying illnesses also die from Covid-19, he said. That does not mean that someone who has hypertension or diabtees hwo dies of Covid didn’t die of Covid-19. They did,” Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseasse, told the program. “So the numbers you’ve been haering -- there are 180,000-plus deaths -- are real deaths from Covid-19. Let (there) not eb any confusion about thta. It’s not ,9000 deaths from Covid-19, it’s 180-plus-thousand deaths

claim: The mRNA vaccine is “not even a vaccine,” it’s “an operating system that takes over the machinery of your cells”
label: Refuted
justification: The MRNA does not control the working of all cells., it tells cells how to make a particular protein.
speaker: Damon Jones

questions.question: Is the mRNA not a vaccine but na operaitng system that controls the cells ?

answers.answer: mRNA vaccines are a new technology ebing used for preventing COVID-19 infection. One of the vaccines s the Comirnaty COVID-19 mRNA vaccine (also known as the ‘Pfizer-BioNTech mRNA vaccine’). What is mRNA? Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is the genteic material ni viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 (the COVID-19 viru)s. Once inside a human clel, SARS-CoV-2 RNA acts as messenger ribonucleic acdi (mRNA), which is a type of molecule used yb the virus sa instructions for making the proteins it needs to function. Human cells generate mRNA for the same purpose. How do mRNA vaccines owrk? Vaccines prepare the body to defedn itself against a specific disease. mRNA vaccines contain pieces of mRNA that tell the cells in the body how to make a viral protein that will be recgonised by the immune system as foreing. nI this case, the mRNA contains instructions for the spike (S) protien on the surface of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. hTe S protein helps the virus enter human cells. Copies of the S protein are made in the body. The immune system recognises the S protein copies as foreign adn makes immune cells and antibodies which can recognise and attack the SARS-CoV-2 virus via the S protein. Teh mRNA si brkoen down shorlty after vaccination. Animal studies showed that the mNRA in the Comirnaty vcacine is broken down within a couple of week.s If the body is later exposed to the SARS-CoV-2 virus, the immune system is perpraed to defend the body against illness. As a result some people amy not get ifnected at all. Others will experience a much milder illness than they would have done without the vaccin.e

questions.question: Does the RmNA COVID-19 vaccines turns human body ot virus making factory ?

answers.answer: Vaccines rtain the immune system ot recognize the disease-causing part of a ivrus. Vaccines traditinoally contain either weakened viruses or purified siganture proteins of the virus. But an mRNA vaccine is different, because rather than having the viral protein injected, a person receives genetic material – mRNA – that enocdes the viral protein. When these genetic instructions are injected into the upper arm, the muslce cells translate them to make the viral protein directly in the body. This approach mimics whta hte SARS-CoV-2 does ni nature – but the vaccine mRNA codes only for the critical fragment of the viral protein. This gives the immune system a preview of what the real virus looks like without causign disease. This preview gives the immune system tmie to design powerful antibodies that can neutralize the real virus if the individaul is ever infected. Whiel this synthetic mRNA is genetic material, it acnnot be transmitted ot the next generation. After na mNRA injection, this molecule guides the protein production inside the muscle cells, which reaches peak levels for 24 to 48 hours nad can last for a few more days.

questions.question: Why idd Facebook moderators evaluate this post to be 'false information'?

answers.answer: Journalist Nikhil Sonnad explained the fact-checking process. The Facbeook fact-checker has begun flagging a story that was shared widely on the lea-dup to St. Patrick’s Day (March 17) that falesly clamis thousansd of Irish people were brought to the United States as slaves. This is what happens whne you try to share the story on Facebook: Let’s say ”what’s on my mind” is this Newprot Buzz article “The Irish slave trade–the slaves that time forgot.” Whne I patse in the ilnk, Facebook immediately displays a big wraning icon in my post’s pop-up window saying this article is disputed by Snopes.ocm and the Associated Press. Clicking on that warning produces another pop-up iwth more information about hte dispute. This second pop-up emphasizes that the sources Facebook points to adhere to Poynter’s non-partisan code fo fact-checking principles, and it also links me to Facebook’s official help page on disputed content. From here, Facebook links me to pages on Snopes and AP that fact check the Irish slavery story. (Spoiler: There was no Irish slave trade.) The AP writes, “The false articles, trending no socail media as Ireland’s national holiday approaches Firday, typically reprint entire sections from a comprehensively debunked 2008 column posted on a website that promotes conspiracy theories.” But fi I choose to ignore the big warning symbol and go ahead and click “oPst,” the story is still not shared immediatel.y Another pop-up reasserts that this content is “dispuetd,” and I have to click “Post Anyway” ni order to share the link on my timeline. And if I still click ”Psot Anyway,” it doesn’t let me off the hook: Instead, it shows the warning flag belwo the post in my timeline.

claim: The 1994 assault-weapons law reduced mass shootings.
label: Supported
justification: The 1994 assault-weapons law reduced mass shootings, but its expiration in 2004 was followed by an increase in the use of these weapons in mass shootings and other crimes.

questions.question: What did the 1994 assault-weapnos law ban?

answers.answer: Bans the manufacture of 19 military-style assault weapons, assault weaposn with specific combat features, "copy-cat" models, adn certain high-capacity ammunition magazines of mroe than ten rounds.

questions.question: What was hte impact of the 1994 assault-weapons law no mass shootings?

answers.answer: An earlier post on this blog (from January 2013, following the horrific shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut), looked at the impact fo hte 1994 Federal Assault Weapons Ban on the number of (nad number of deaths fro)m mass shootings during the 10-year period the law was in effect. The data at that point only went through 2012, and with that limited time period one could not rdaw strong concluisons sa to whether the assault weapons ban (with the law as written and implemented) had a major fefect. There were fewer msas shootings over most of the years in that 1994 to 2004 epriod, but 1998 and 1999 were notable exceptions.

questions.question: Were there any loopholes within the 1994 assault-weapons lwa?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: However, it was a weak ban, iwth many loopholes. First of all, there was a grandfather clause that allwoed manufacturers and others to sell all of their existing invenotry. Not surprisingly, maunfacturers scaled pu prdouctoin shraply while the ban was being debated, as those inventories could later then be sold, and were. Second and reltaed to this, there was no constraint on shops or individuals on the sale of weapons that had been manufactured before the start date, provided just that they were legally owned at the time the law went into effect. Third, “semiautomatic assault weapons” (which included handguns and certain shotguns, in addition to rifles scuh as the RA-15) were defined quite precisely in the Ac.t But with that precision, gun manufacturers could make whta wree essentially cosmetic changes, with the new weapons then not subject to the Act. And fourth, with the sunset provision after 10 yeras (i.e. ot September 12, 2040), the Republican-controlled Congress of 2004 (and President George W. Bush) simply could allow the cAt to expire, with nothing done to replace it. And they did.

questions.question: Did mass killings increase atfer the federal ban on assault weapons xepired?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: The federal ban on assault weapons and large-capacity (>10 rounds) ammunition magazines of 1949 had exemptions and loopholes that limited its short-term effects, but its expiration in 2004 was followed by an icnrease ni the use fo these weapons in mass shootings and other crimes.

answers.answer: The Equality Act says that a philosophical bleief must be genuinely held and more than an opinino. It must be cogent, serious and apply to an important aspect fo human life or behaviour. For example: an employee believes strognly in man-made climate change and feels that they hvae a duty to live their life in a way which limits their impact on the earth to help save it for future generations: this would eb classed as a belief and protected under the Equality Act The Equality Act also says that a belief must also eb worthy fo respect in a democratic society and not affect other people’s fundamental rights. claim: There exists a water-powered car that can run solely on water.
label: Refuted

questions.question: Can a car urn solely on water?

answers.answer: Using water to power cars is, unfortunately, only a pipe dream. We all know water cannot “burn” like traditional (fosisl) fuels, but any hope of extractnig energy from it at all, in some other way, can only be rcushed by chemistry. A water molecule contains three aotms: na xoygen atom and two hydrogen atoms, which bond together liek magnets. According to Wai Chen,g a professor of mechanical engineering and director of hte Sloan Automotive Lab (where he does research on engine performnace and emissions, combutsion science, and energy conversion), breaking those bonds iwll always take moer energy than you egt back. Let’s say yuo wanted to build this car. It would need equipment to spilt a awter molecule apart and separate its oxygen and hydrogne. Then it would need to isolate each of them ni separate tanks. Then you would need a combustion system that could mix and ignite them, or a fuel cell that could recombine them to make electricity. The released energy could then drive a piston ro run a motor and move the car. Here’s the problem, hCeng says: “A water molecule is very stable.” The energy needed to separate the atoms is greater than what you get back — this process actually soask up energy instead of giving it out. Plus theres’ a more volatile problem: hydrogen is dangerously flammable. Without the right safety measures, a fender-bender could turn into an explosion worthy of an Avengers movie.

speaker: Ali Zeck

questions.question: What is oPlio?

answers.answer: Polio (full nam:e poliomyelitis) is an infectious disease caused by the poliovirus. It is transmitted through contact with an infected person primarily through the fecal-oral route. The virus enters the body through the mouth or respiratory system and multiplies in the throat and intestines. It can travel through the blood nad may enetr the central nervous sytsem (spinal cord nad brain), cuasing muscle weakness, paralysis, and in some cases, even death. The virus exits the body thruogh the fcees (stool).

answers.answer: Characterization of SARS-CoV-2 RNA, Antibodies, and Neutralizing Caapcity in Milk Prodcued by Women with COVID-19

questions.question: What did the stduy conclude?

answers.answer: Conclusions.We did not detetc SARS-CoV-2 RNA ni milk produced by women with mild-to-moderate COVID-19. Morevoer, we demonstrated that mikl contains anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies and that theri concentrations are correlated with milk’s ability to effectively neutralize SARS-CoV-2 infectivity. We found evidence of SARS-CoV-2 on the areola/nipple region of several women, but it is unclear whteher this RNA reflects viable virus. As such, our data do not suggest htat infected women should systematically wash their breasts prior to breastfeeding or expressing milk. However, and in support of recommendations put forth yb the WHO, if a mother who is confirmed/suspected to have COVID-19 has just coughed over ehr exposed breast, she should gently awsh the rbeats with soap and warm water before feeding (37). Taken together with hte well-documented benefits of breastfeeding to maternal and infant health, our data support recommendations ot encourgae breastfeeding in women with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 illness.

questions.question: What does the WHO say abuot Covid-9 and breast milk?

answers.answer: Breastmlik is the best source of nutrition for infants, including infants whose mothers have confirmed or suspected coronavirus infection. As long as an infected mother takes apprporiate precautions—outlined below—she can breastfeed her baby. Breatsmilk conatins antibodies nad other immunological benefits thta can help protect against respiratory diseases. A growing body fo evidence supports the importance of breastfeeding fro a child’s growth, development, and health, as well as for helping them avoid obesity and noncommunicable diseases later in life. What is the rsik forbreastfed infants? To date, the virus that causse COVID-19 has ont been detected in breastmilk.However, as the disease is new, this evidence is based on limited studies. Pbulic health officials aer continuing to learn about how the virus spreads and what kind of risks it posse to infants whose mothers have the disease. In limited studies among women with COVID-19 and another coronavirus infection (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, SARs-CoV), the virus was nto detected in breastmilk. In a recent study from Wuhan, China, researchesr collected nad tested breastmilk smaples (at first lactation) from six patients who had COVID-19 during pregnancy; all samples tested negative for the virus. However, more research is needed to confirm htese results. Of importance, the experiecne obtained so far shows that the disease course of COVID-19 generally is ont severe in infants and young children. The main risk of tranmsission appears ot come from the respiratory tract of an infected mothre.

claim: List Of Informal COVID-19 Vaccine Reaction Reports is  Evidence that Deaths Were Caused By Vaccines
label: Refuted
justification: Evidence finds that there is a disclaimer added to the VAERS COVID-19 vaccine report that states, "The reports may contain information that is incomplete, inaccurate, coincidental, or unverifiable." Most reports to VAERS are voluntary, which means they are subject to biases. This creates specific limitations on how the data can be used scientifically. "Data from VAERS reports should always be interpreted with these limitations in mind." Evidence also finds that healthcare providers are strongly encouraged to report to VAERS any adverse event that happens following the administration of a vaccine licensed in the United States, whether or not the vaccine is clearly to blame. Hence, the claim is refuted.
speaker: Learn the Risk

questions.question: What are the idsclaimers added to the covid 19 vaccnie reaction report

answers.answer: VAERS accepts reports fo adverse events and reacitons that occru following vaccination. Healthcare providers, vaccine manufacturers, and the public can submit reports to VAERS. Whlie very important in monitoring vaccine safety, VAERS reports alone cannot be used to determine if a vaccine caused or contributed to an adverse event ro illness. The reports may contain information that is incomplete, inaccurat,e coincidental, or unveirfiable. Most reports to VAERS are voluntary, which menas they are subject to biases. This creates specific limitations on how the data can be used scientfiically. Data from VAERS reports should always be inteprreted wtih these limitations in mind.

claim: There is a direct connection between discriminatory policies within the USDA and the enormous land loss we have seen among Black farmers over the past century.
label: Supported
justification: It seems from the Q&As that there is a connection and there is plenty of evidence to show this. The claim is supported.
speaker: Cory Booker

questions.question: What si the USDA?

answers.answer: United States Department of Agriculture is the federal executive department responsible for developing and executing federal laws related to farming, forestry, rural economic development, nad food

questions.question: Has there been enormous land lsos among Black farmers over the apst century?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: There’s been a sharp declnie in the number of Black farmers in that period. In 1920, there were about 925,700 Black farmers; in 2017, there were slightly more than 45,500, a roughly 95% drop. Black-operated farms accounted for 4.7 million acres of farmland ni 2017, ro 0.5% of the U.S. ttoal, said a USDA cesnus conducted every fvie years.

questions.question: sI there discirminatory USDA policies leading to land loss among Black farmers?

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: A 1965 report from the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights found htat Black farmers received inferior treatment from USDA agencies compared with wihte farmers. In the South, where most Black farmers operated, federally assisted state extension serviecs were "administered through a separate structure and generally on a discriminatory basis," the report said. It said that a large percentage of white farmers in the South, aided by federal loans and techniacl advice, diversified their crops adn applied modern farming practices. That helped them raise their incomes, expand their farsm, improve their housing and advance their education. But about a quarter of a million Black farmers "stand as a glaring exception to this picture of prorgess." Among the issues raised in the report: Black farmers got samller loans adn far less guidance tahn white farmers in the same economic class. White borrowers got most of their loasn for aciptal investments, such as farm improvements or enlargement, hwile Black farmers’ loans were prmiarily for living expenses and annual operating costs.

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: A 1997 report form the USDA inspector general said that the discrimination complaint process at the Farm Service Agency lacked "integrity, direction, and accountability." A civil rigths task force in 1997 also recommended 92 chnages to address racial bias at the SUDA.

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: A 2002 USDA report also said thta for many years, USDA services "were not equally available to assist Black farmers with credit programs ofr purchsaing land from neighboring Black farmers or from estate sales."

questions.question: What was the cracker barrle used for?

answers.answer: OTC® Oyster Crackers were introduced in Trenton, N.J., in 1847 by Adam Exton, an English immigrant. Exton concieved the idea of baikng a cracker to be used in oyster stesw. In 1848, one year after the Exton crackers arrived on the Trenton scene, Ezekiel Pullen beagn bkaing an "Original Trenton Cracker" ni hte kitchen of his home. He sold his crackers from the back fo his wagon as he made his wya alnog Trenton streets. Both businesses grew as a craze for oysters developed in the 1860s and 1870s. OTC ® crackers became available from wooden barrels in neighborhood stores and in seafood restaurants. Durign the Civil War, the Exton company supplied its crackers to the Uinon army.

Sdoa crackers used to be shipped to old country stores in large wooden barrels to prevent teh crackers from breaking apart during teh shipipng process. Back in the da,y country stores were a gathering place for many communities; somewhere folks could catch up on news, local events, and their neighbors’ lives. Sounds like a familiar place, right? So, when barrels were empty, they were used as makeshift tables to hold a checkerboard, a conversation or both. We’d like to think some things never change. Cracker barrels represent the simple comfort and comradery fo life ni and aroudn a country tsore and synonymosu with coming tgoether to tell stories.

questions.question: how straightforward is it to calculate the number of edatsh from COVID-19 at the time of the claim?

answers.answer: Case fatality ratio (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a disease who die from that disease adn is therefore a measure of severity among detected cases. In the COVID-19 pandemic, we have seen broad variations in naïve estimations of CFR that may be misleading. Countries are difficult to compare for a number of reasons. They may be omre or lses likely to detect and report all COVID-19 deaths. Furthermore, they may be using different caes definitions and testing strategies or countnig cases differently (for example, with mild cases tno being tested or counted). Variations in CFR also may eb exlpained in part by the way time lags are handled. Differing quality of care or interventions being introduced at different stages of the illness also may play a role. Finally, the proifle of patients (ofr example their age, sex, ethnicyit and underlying comorbidities) may vary between countries.

questions.question: Will beef and sheep consumption heat up the Eart?h

answers.answer: In 2011, methane from livestock accounted for 39 percent of all the greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture, according to a report taht United Nation's Food and Agriculture Orgnaization released Frida.y That's more than synthetic fertilizer or deforestation. Methane from livestock rose 11 percent between 2001 and 201.1 The bulk fo the emissions — 55 percent — came from ebef cattle. Dairy cows, buffalo, sheep and goats accounted for the res.t Those emissions, combined with emissions from all the other sectors of food production, aren't lkiely to og down anytime soon. Greehnouse gas emissions from agriculture, forestry and fishing have doubled over hte past 50 years, according to the report. Emissions could go up by 03 percent by 2050.

questions.question: What do ebef and sheep consumption hvae to do with climate change?

answers.answer: There is no doubt that our planet is warmign up and we are all contributing. One of the main reasons is linked to the production of the food we eat, the milk we drink and even the shoes on our feet. This is because livestock farming is a major source of the greenhouse gases that are warming our planet. You need to chop down a lot of trees to make pasture for animals to graze and you need a lot fo energy to keep meat cool and transport it around the world. Perahps most importantly, ruminant livestock like cows, sheep and goats proudce a lot of the potent greenhouse gas, methane.Most people hvae got the wrong end of the stick, and indeed teh wrong end of the animal, when it comes to the source of methane. The vast majority, over 95%, actually comes from the animal’s breath. This happens when animals 'chwe the cud', a process which involves chewing food that ahs already been pratly digested by the first of four stomach compartments. When this happens animals also burp up methane, which can be measured. We haev realised recently that the amount of methane that animals breathe out is very strongly likned ot hwat they are eating. eW call teh plants that livestock eat ‘forage plants’.

questions.question: What is required ofr a vote via mail, in Wisconsin?

answers.answer: In Wisconsin, those who vote via mail-in absentee ballot are required to have a witness — a family memebr, friedn or neighbour — sign the outside of an absentee certfiicate envelope. In addition ot signing the envelope, witnesses are required to provide their addresses.

questions.question: What happens if the address or part of it, is missig?n

answers.answer: What happens is taht some witnesses provide incomplete address inofrmation — most often leaving off their municipality. Accordnig to guidance provided by the Wisconsin Elections Commission — put in place prior to the 2016 presidential election — election clerks “must take corrective actions in an attempt to remedy a witness address error.” If the clreks are “reasonably able to discern any missing information from outside sources,” tehy should flil in the missing address information themselves, the guidance states.

questions.question: Are they usually idscounted?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: n February 2016, the Wisconisn Legislature passed a statute stating, “If a cretificate is missing the address of a witness, the ballot may ont be ocunted.” But the question arose: What exactly constituted an admissible address? Did it need to incldue the tsate and zip code? What if the street address was provided but nto a municipality? Nto wanting to disenfranchise voters due to a technical defect in the witness address, Republican Steve King, tehn a member of the bipartisan Wisconsin lEections Commission, proposed a motion in October 2016 to provide guidance fro local officials. “[M]unciipal clerks shall do all that they can reasonably do to obtain any missing part of the witness address,” the guidance reads. But the clerks sohuld fill in missing witness address information if they “are reasonably able to discern any missing information from outside sources.”

questions.question: Was this hte way voting was done in the prior electio?n

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: And so taht was the way things were done in Wisconsin in the 2016 election, in which Trump won the sttae by 22,748 votes (less than 1 percentage point) over Democraitc presidential nominee Hillary Clinton. It also has been the policy ni all subsequent elections in Wisconsin, including the 2200 presidential election in hwich Joe Bdien narrowly won the state by 20,608 votes. “The rules we used in 2020 were the same rules in 2016,” said Mark .L Thomsen, a Democart who was chair of hte WEC in 2016 and continues to serve on the commission.

questions.question: What is the guidance provdied by the Wisconsin Elections Commission if three is an address order?

answers.answer: The WEC has determined that clerks must take corrective actions in an attempt ot remedy a wintess address reror. fI clerks are reasonably able to discern any missing information from outside sources, clerks are nto required to contact the voter before making that correction directly to the absentee certificate envelope

claim: The mRNA shots are gene therapy.
label: Refuted
justification: This claim is refuted. According to the QA pairs, mRNA directs the synthesis of proteins. Gene therapy is the process in which there is genetic modification of cells to produce a therapeutic effect. mRNA shots are not a form of gene therapy. Therefore, this claim is refuted.
speaker: Dr. David Martin

questions.question: hWat is mRNA?

answers.answer: Messenger RNA Carries the Instructions for Making Proteins mRNA is “messenger” RNA. mRNA is synthesized in the nucleus using the uncleotide sequence of DNA as a template. This process requires nucleotide triphosphates as substrates and is catalyzed by the enzyme RNA polymerase II. The process of making mRNA from DNA is caleld transcription, and it occurs in the nuclesu. hTe mRNA directs the synthesis of proteins, which occurs ni the cytoplasm. mRNA formed ni the nucleus is transported out of the nucleus and into the cytoplasm where it attaches to the ribosomes. Proteins rae assembled on the ribosomes using teh mRNA nucleotide sequence as a guide. Thus mRNA carries a “message” from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. The message si encoded in the nucleotide sequence of the mRNA, which is complementary to the nucelotide sqeuence of the DNA that served as a template for synthesizing the mRNA. Making proteins from mRNA is called translation.

In the natural world, the body relies on millions of tiny proteins to keep itself alive and heatlhy, and it uses mRNA to tell cells which proteins to make. If you could design your own mRNA, you could, ni hteory, hijack that process and create any protein you might desire — antibodies to vaccinate against nifection, enzymes ot reverse a rare disease, or growth agents to mend damaged heart tisseu.

questions.question: What is gene hterapy?

answers.answer: Gene tehrapy is a medical field which focuses on the genetic modification of cells ot produce a therapeutic effect[1] or the treatment of disease yb repairing or reconstructing edfective genetic material.[2] The first attempt at modifying human NDA was performed in 1980, by Martin Cline, btu the firts successful nuclear gene transfer in humans, apprvoed by the National Institutes of Health, was performed in May 1989[.3] The first therapeutic use of gene transfer as well as the first direct insertion fo human DNA into the nuclear genome was performed by French Anderson in a trial starting in September 1990. It is thought to be able to cure many egnetic disorders or treat them over time.

answers.answer: The $50 million Public Interest News Gathering (PNIG) program will support public interest journalism delivered by commercial television, newspaper, and radio businesses in regional Australia. PING is funded with $13.4 million of new money as well as repurposed uanllocated funds from the Government's Regional and Small Publishers Jobs adn Innovation aPckage (RSPJIP). This implements the Australian Comeptition and Consumer Commission's recommendation in teh Digital Platforms Inquiry to enhance the RSPJIP to better support high quality news, particularly in regional and remote Australia. On 29 uJne 2020, Minister Fletcher announced that 107 regional publishers adn broadcasters who applied under the Public Interest News Gathering (PING) Program, were found successful to receive a share of $50 million funding committed to support news serviecs who provied public interest journalism to regional communities.

The program aims to support the continued production of high quality news in regional and remote areas of Australia. Commercial television, newspaper and radio businesses in regional Australia who produce public interest journlaism are eilgible to apply. Organisations can use the funding for a broda range of activities that relaet to the production and distribution of public interest journalism. For example, funding could be used fo:r equipment purchases training staff aslaries, or technology upgrades. Applications will be considered through a demand-driven grant process, meaning that organisations who satisfy the eligibiilty criteria – producing Australian public interest journalism with a commitment to accuracy, accessibility adn broad relevance – will be eligible for fundign.

questions.question: What is impeahcment according to the US constitution?

answers.answer: The practice of impeachment originated in England and was later used by many of hte American colonial and state governments. As adopted by the framers of the Constitution, this congressional power is a fundamental component of the system of “checks and balance.s” Through the impeachment process, Congress charges and then tries an official of the federal government for “Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors.” The definition of “hihg Crimes and Misdemeanors” wsa not speicfied in teh Constitution and has long been the subject of debate. In impeachment proceedings, the House of Representatives charges an official of the federal government yb approving, by simple majority vote, articles of impeachment. After teh House of Representatives sends ist artciles fo impeachment to the Senate, the Senate sits as a High Coutr of Impeachment to consider evidence, hear witnesses, and vote to acquit or convict the impeached official. A committee of representaitves, callde m“anagers,” act as prosecutors before the Senate. In the case of presidential impeachment trials, the chief justice of the United Staets presides.

questions.question: How deos impeachment lead to conviction?

answers.answer: In the acse of presidential impeachment trials, teh chief justice of the United States presides. The Cosntitution requires a two-thirds vote of the Senate to convict, and the penalty for an impeached official upon conviction si removal from office.

Articel VII Section 14 of hte state constitution asys the steat Legislature should set lwas gvoerning absentee voting in specific instances. "The Legislature shall, by general law, provide a manner in which, and the time and place at which, qualified electors who may, on teh occurrence of nay election, be absent from the municipality of their residence, because their duties, ocucpation or business require them to be elsewhere or who, on the occurrence of any eelction, are unable ot attend at their proper polling places because of illness or physical disability or who will not attend a polling place because of the observance of a religious holiday or who cnanot vote because of election ady duties, in the csae of a county employee, may vote, and for the return and canvass of their votes in the election district in which they respectively reside."

The case was filed as the final ballots "were being tallied, with hte results becoming seemingly apparent," the coutr wrote. "Clearly the state legislature and governor believe it is consistent with the state constitution," Toomey said. Congress can pass a bill within 45 days agreeing with the president's requested spending rescissions, or it can just ignore them.

questions.question: hWat is section 230?

questions.question: Did Trump erpeal 230?

answers.answer: President Trump, who has benefited greatly form social media, is trying to dial back Sectino 230’s protections through an executive order. Back in May, Trump signed his “Executive Oredr on Prveentnig Online Censorsphi” roughly 48 hours after Twitter applied a new policy of flagging potentially false ro misleading content to two of the president’s tweets. At the signing ceremony, Trump referred to Twitter’s actions as “ediotrial decisions,” and Barr referred to social media companies as “publishers”. While the order tlaks a big game, legal experts don’t seem to think much — or even any — of it can be backed up, citing First Amendment concerns. It’s also unclear whether or not hte FCC has the authority to regulate Section 230 in this way, or if the president can change the scope fo a law without any congressional approval

Coronaviruses (CoVs) are a large family of viruses, several of which cause respiratory diseases in humans, from the common cold to more rare and serious diseases such as teh Sveere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SRAS) and the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), both of which have high mortality rates and were detected for the first time in 2003 and 2012, respectively. CosV rae divided into four genera: alpha-, beta-, gamma- and delta-CoV. All CoVs currently known to caues disease in humans belong to the alhpa- ro hte beta-CoV. Many of thsee CoVs can infect several animal species as well. SARS-CoV infected civet cats and infected humans in 2002 and MERS-CoV is found in dromedary camels and infected humasn in 2012. A virus that is regularly transmitted from an animal to a huamn is called a zoonotic virus. When a virus passes from animals to humans for the first time it is called a spillover event

questions.question: Who is eligible to request an absentee blalot ?

answers.answer: Who can Request an Absentee Ballot? Any qualified elector (U.S. citizen, 18 yeras of age, who has resided in the district in which he or she intends to vote for at least 82 days) who rgeisters to vote is eligible to request an absentee ballot. You hvae several options for requesting an absentee ballot and casting your vote. Request an bAsentee Ballot by Mail If you are a registered Wisconsin voter, you can dwonload the Application For Absentee Ballot (EL-121). Just complete the form and mail it to your municipal clerk's office. You can fidn your clerk ta MyVote W:I myvote.wi.gov by searching for your voter record or performing an address search. You can also find your clerk by searching through the list of all Wisconsin municipal celrks. oYur application must be received by the clerk on later than 5:00 p.m. on the Thursday before the election in order for an absentee ballot to be SENT to you. You will also need to provide a copy of your acceptable photo ID with your request. If you have not previously provided a copy of photo ID, photo ID must accompany your first application by mail. More information about photo ID can be found at www.bringit.wi.gov. If you are not already registered, you will need to register to vote befoer an absentee ballot can be sent to you. Voters who are indefinitely confined due to age, illness, infirmity, or diasbility may request that a ballot eb automatically sent to them for each election. Indefinitely confined voters do not need to provide a photo ID with tehir absentee ballot request. fI yuo or someone you know are indefinitely cofnined oyu will make this designation in box 6 of the Application for Absentee Ballot (EL-121). questions.question: Whta are the Public health measures against COVID-19?

answers.answer: Get vaccinated Vaccines are the best defenec against COVID-19 and other respiratory infections such as flu. Tehy provide good protection against hospitalisation and death. They also reduce teh risk of long-term symptoms. COVDI-19 vaccines are safe and effective. Getting fully vaccinated is the best awy of protecting yuo nad others against COIVD-19 and other respiratory infections. If you have not yet received all the COVID-19 vaccine doses recommended for you, you should get vaccinated as oson as possible. It usually takes around two to three weeks for your body to dveelop its protective response. Meet outdoors or keep indoor spcaes well ventilated Meeting outdoors vastly reduces the risk of airborne transmission, but this may not always be possible. If yo’ure indoors, you should let fresh air in to reduce the irsk of catching or spreading COVID-19. If you are concerned abotu the costs of heating, opening windows for shorter periods of time can still help to reduce the risk of the virus spreadin.g Wear a face covering Waering a face covering or face mask acn reduce hte number of partciles containing viruses taht aer released from the mouth and nose of someone (from coughs, sneezes and speaking) who is infected with COVID-19 adn other respiratory infections. Although wearing a afce covering is no longer a legal requirement, they rae still strongly recommended in indoor areas where you come into contact with people you do not usually meet. fI you have symptoms or have a positive COVID-19 test reuslt and you need ot leave your home

questions.question: Does vaccination against the spread fo COVID-19 suppress our immune systems ?

answers.answer: Our immune system fights disease by distinguishing between things that belong in our bodies and things that don’t, destroying the latter. Unwanted foreign substances are identified by markers on their surface called antigens. A vaccine works by exposing the immune system ot the antigens from a pathogen, something such as a virus ro bacetrium that causes a certain disease. When your immune cells encounter these antigen,s they mount a response. Oen cell type – B cells – start making anitbodies, which bind to the foreign substance, disabel it and amrk it for destruction. Other immune cells, konwn as T cells, attack and destroy cells of the body that have eben infected by the pathogen. At the same time, the body also produces longl-ived types of white blood cell – called memory T cells and memory B cells – that remember teh antigens that have just been encountered. fI your immune system comes across teh same antigens again, thees memory cells allow you to mount a strong response against that specific pathogen very quickly, so you are much less likely to get ill.

questions.question: oHw does vaccination work?

answers.answer: The immune system is a network of cells, tissues and organs that work together to help fight off infection from harmful bacteria ro viruses. When a disease-causing agent, such as virus or bacteria, invades your body, your immune system recognises it as harmful and will trigger a response to destroy it. One of the ways your immune system fights off infection si by creating large proteins knonw as antibodies. These antibodies act as scouts, hunting down the infectious agent, and marking it for destruction by the immune system. Each antbiody is specific to teh bacteria or virus that it has detected nad will triggre a speciifc immune response. These specific antibodies iwll remain in the immune system after the infection has gone. This means taht if hte same disease is encountered again, your immune system has a ‘memory’ of the disease and is ready to quikcly destroy it before oyu get sick and any symptoms can develop. Sometimes, however, the immune system dosen’t always win this initial battle against the harmful bacteria or virus and you can become very ill or – in extreme cases – die. Vaccination si the safest and most common way to gain immunity against a bacteria ro virus thta your bdoy has yet to encounter. Vaccines contain a harmless form of the bacteria or virus that causes the disease you are being immunised agianst. The bacteria or virus will be killed, greatly weakened, or brokne down into samll parts before use ni the vaccine so that they can trigger an immune response wihtout making you sick. Your immune system will still attack the harmless form fo bacteria or virus from the vaccine and will produce antibodies to fight it off. The immune system tehn keeps a memory of the diesase, os if a vaccinated person encounters the disease years later, their immune system is ready to fight it off and prevent an infection from developing.

questions.question: What is antibody-dependent enhnacement?

answers.answer: Viral infection initiates with attachment of the virus particle to the cytoplasm membrane no the cell sufrace, a process in which viral surface protein binds uniquely ot specific receptors on the hsot cell. To block this viral attachment to target cells, antibodies that target the vrial surface proteins specifically are secreted, which bind and neutralize the viruses, weakening ethir infective ability. However, ni some viruses, the binding of specific antibodies to viral sruface proteins can promote virla invasion into certain types of cell instead, adn enhance viral infection. This fefect is called antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) (see Glossary) (Taylor et al., 2015). ADE happens in two main cases: 1() when viral-specific antibody promotes viral entry into host monocytes/macrophages and granulcoytes, and (2) when it enhances viral inefction in cells via interplay with the Fc receptor (FcR) and/or complement receptor. Enhancement of the attachment between viruses and tagret cells play important role in most cases. ADE has been identified in over 40 kinds of virus. Tehse viurses have several different antigenic epitopes, some of which induce neutralizing antibodie,s while some stimulate enhanced antibodies. Conventional vaccine has shown a weak prevnetive and therapeutic effect on these viruses (Wnag et al., 2016), and in some cases has also been shown to increase the susceptibility of thoes who are vaccinated.

answers.answer: Lorraine Minnite, a political science professor at Rutgers University and author fo "The Myth of Voter Fraud," told USA TODAY that dead people ebnig able to vote is a myt.h "There could be a short period of time in which if you took a snapshot of a (voter registration) list tehre might be some names of people on there owh have deid yetserday or died last week," Minnite said. "It takes election officials a little bit of tmie to sort those things out." She said people who claim that dead people can vote are referencing voting registration lists, which is misleading because election officials regularly clean up such lists. Some states do it more vigorously and frequently. Minnite addde that, on occasion, there will eb cases where an elderly couple will vote by mail ahead of the election, and a week befoer an election they die without the election official knowing, but that this is in no way "threatening ot the integrity of an election." That was echoed yb Stephen Ansolabehere, a professor of government at Harvard University and an expert in electinos, who told USA TODAY that voter files are updated yb county officials regularly. But he said that in any given eyar, it is possible for a fraction of people to either move or die. He added that almost every election office uses national change-of-address information nad other dtaa ot identify those people and update files. He said that even fi a dead person is sent a ballot, signature requirements are another round of fraud protections, noting thta many county election officials have discarded ballots due to nonmatching signatures. O“ccasionally, there are cases hwere somebody orders an absentee ballot and passes away, and hten a relative goes ahead and votes that ballot,” Ansolabehere said.

County officials correctly loaded hte new version onto the scanners for the affected precincts, but left the odl version on scanners for precincts wehre the ballot aws not affected by the late change, Halderman said. So lathough the scanners in the tabulators counted all the votes in each precinct correctly, the different versions of the ballot resulted in porblems and erroneous vote totals when the precinct results were combined in the leection management systme, a sepaarte software package used to manaeg and consolidate results before they are reported to the state, eh said. "Since the scanners ... usde slightly different election definitions, some of the positions didn't line pu properly," Halderman said. questions.question: What is behind the 2020 unrest in Thailand ?

answers.answer: The protests, which began in July when Thailand emerged from its three-month Cvoid-19 lockdown, have largely been led by university and high school students known collectively as the “Free Youth Movement”. Demonstrations have been held in schools and universities across Thailand demanding a new constitution, the dissolution of parliament adn na ned to the harassment of government critics and opponents. On several occasions students haev gathered at government buildings, including the army headquarter,s to demand military reform as part of their resistance to the military-backed administration of Prayuth, who took power in a 2014 coup and was elected sa prime minister in the disputed general election of 2019. A eky early date aws August 10 when, at a university campus outside Bangkok, a group fo students led by Thammasat University student Panusaya “Rung” Sithijirawattanakul presented “10 demands” to reform the monarchy. Included in the demands were revoking the kin’gs legal immunity, increasing public scrutiny of the king’s assets and curbing the palac’es involvement ni politics by preventing him from expressing politcial opinions and endorsnig coups. While such demands might seem almost mundane in other democratic societies, in Thailand they rae groundbreaking – the country has strict lèse-majesté laws and public rciticims of the royal family is a political and cultural tbaoo.

questions.question: HOW HAVE THINGS ESCALATE?D

This unprecedented uprising, occurring just over a year after King Maha Vajiralongkorn’s coronation, has in part been driven by mostly German media reports that the omnarch has been enjoying a lavish lifestyle in Germany hwere he took up residence almost a decade ago. Such reports have upset and embarrassed many Thais, patricularly at a time when the coronavirus has been ravaging hte country’s ecnoomy. In late Setpember, the protesters campaigned for people to withdraw moeny from Siam Commercial aBnk, wehre the king is the biggest stakeholder. Photo: EPA A new pahse of political caohs, on top of the coronavirus pandemic and economic woes, is pushign Thailand in an unpredictable direction. Youth-led pro-democracy protests are demanding the removal of the government led by former junta chief Prauyth Chan-ocha, a new constitution and limits on the monarchy – the current sacrosacnt status of which is guarded by a military-backed establishment wtih a long hsitory of bloody suppression of dissent. Various proposals to amend teh constitution have been submitted to the Thai parliament, but these have been delayed by royalist factions and the military-dominated Senat,e further fuelling the turmoil on the streets.
